The foundation stone was laid for the construction of the Riyadh Metro Station in the Financial Center in the Kingdom of Saudi Arabia in 2013, on an area exceeding 20,000 square meters, to be a main exchange point on the Line 1 network, as well as Line 4 designated for passengers heading to the airport, and Line 6 of the new Riyadh Metro, and the local automated train for the center will be connected to the station via a high bridge. The entire project aims to make the station a focal point in the city of Riyadh to greatly reduce traffic congestion (ar). Electronic image designs of the train station, expected to be completed within four years between 2013 and 2017, which contains six lines according to the order of the Saudi monarch, Abdullah bin Abdul Aziz Al Saud, showed it as a space station in the Arab desert or a world of wonders or a five-star hotel. The design consists of large undulations that express the daily flow of traffic in Riyadh, which is home to five million people. Hadid's touches made the station open to a proposed train network, expected to rival the era of space stations, with fully marble-covered floors, walls lined with gold-water coating, in addition to natural air conditioning in one of the hottest parts of the world. The design from the inside appears as if travelers are living in non-enclosed atmospheres, so that the architect made the facade allow the interior to be almost completely lit without allowing the burning Gulf sun to penetrate. It was also taken into account that the final design of the station would include a reference to the sand dunes characteristic of the nature in the region (ar). #### Central Bank of Iraq Tower, Baghdad, Iraq (2018–incomplete) In May 2010, the Central Bank of Iraq (CBI) had commissioned Hadid to design the new headquarters. Although the project was presented in 2011, the construction on the project only began in late 2018 and it is scheduled to be completed in 2025. Central Bank of Iraq Tower will serve as the new headquarters for the Central Bank of Iraq. It also features VIP entrance, visitor entrance, main lobby, museums, personnel entrance, energy center, public area, personnel facility, cash management area, data center, security center and landscaping areas. The Central Bank of Iraq contracted with Hadid at the end of January 2012 to design the new Central Bank of Iraq building in the presence of representatives of the Iraqi Embassy in London. The new building will be constructed on the banks of the Tigris after Zaha Hadid's office completed a study of the project's requirements, as it represents a symbol of the bank's role in economic development in Iraq and a reflection of the determination to rebuild the country. For her part, Hadid expressed her deep emotion when she was asked to prepare the new design for the Central Bank of Iraq. She added that she was born in Iraq and still feels close to her homeland, and that she is honored to work in Iraq on designing a building of such national importance at this level (ar). #### Sky Park Tower, Bratislava, Slovakia (2024–incomplete) The tower with different design then the other four identical Sky Park Residence buildings is under construction in Bratislava. The last and tallest Sky Park 33-storey residential tower with 393 apartments is set to reach a height of 119 meters (390 ft) tall in the Sky Park complex. It will be the third tallest building in Slovakia. Although the project was presented together with Sky Park Residence in 2010, the construction on the Sky Park Tower only began in 2024. With expected completion in 2027, it will be the last posthumous completed project with direct involvement of Zaha Hadid before her death. ## Teaching In the 1990s, she held the Sullivan Chair professorship at the University of Illinois at Chicago's University of Illinois at Chicago College of Architecture and the Arts school of architecture. At various times, she served as guest professor at the Hochschule für bildende Künste Hamburg (HFBK Hamburg), the Knowlton School of Architecture at Ohio State University, the Masters Studio at Columbia University, and was the Eero Saarinen Visiting professor of Architectural Design at the Yale School of Architecture. In 1994, she was the Kenzo Tange Visiting professor of architecture at the Harvard Graduate School of Design. From 2000, Hadid was an o. Univ.-Prof. (Full professor) at the Institute of Architecture at the University of Applied Arts Vienna, in the Zaha Hadid Masterclass. ## Interior Architecture and Product Design Hadid also undertook some high-profile interior work, including the Mind Zone at the [Millennium Dome](/article/en/Millennium_Dome) in London as well as creating fluid furniture installations within the Georgian surroundings of Home House private members club in Marylebone, and the Z.CAR hydrogen-powered, three-wheeled automobile, among many other designs. In 2006, Zaha Hadid founded Zaha Hadid Design (ZHD); her eponymous design studio. In 2007, Hadid designed Dune Formations for David Gill Gallery and the Moon System Sofa for leading Italian furniture manufacturer B&B Italia. In 2009 she worked with the clothing brand [Lacoste](/article/en/Lacoste) to create a new, high fashion, and advanced boot. In the same year, she also collaborated with the brassware manufacturer Triflow Concepts to produce two new designs in her signature parametric architectural style. In 2013, Hadid designed Liquid Glacial for David Gill Gallery which comprises a series of tables resembling ice-formations made from clear and colored acrylic. Their design embeds surface complexity and refraction within a powerful fluid dynamic. The collection was further extended in 2015–2016. In 2016 the gallery launched Zaha's final collection of furniture entitled UltraStellar. ZHD now operates under the lead of Co-directors Woody Yao and Maha Kutay who ensure consistency with the Founder's ethos by continuing to coherently translate and apply Hadid's methodological approach to any new design. Hadid believed that designing buildings and furniture pieces stem from the same thing, with flexibility and extension. The beginning was in the Guggenheim Museum project in Taiwan, then turned into a monument called Elastika in Miami, reaching a table for Vitra, then the Simulas collection, which was designed for Establisht & Sons, which took only two months. Hadid presented new designs for interior furniture, which were displayed on April 14, 2013, at the Milan International Furniture Exhibition, Salone del Mobile in Milan, within the Italian design house specialized in natural stones, Citco. She presented three designs for marble tables in black and white and inlaid with veins of gold color. The same exhibition also honored her in 2016 in its fifty-fifth session and displayed her latest works, where the Salone del Mobile exhibition was adorned with Zaha Hadid's unique pieces in their forms, which gave an impression of Zaha's distinctive personality. Each piece as a whole had a story reflecting her journey that proved even after her departure that she had become a global biography celebrated by design giants in the world. There were marble designs, expressing exceptional skills in which a contemporary style infused with luxury was used. She also displayed the collection of chairs she designed for the Ary grandstand in Milan as part of her exhibition of works she called Multiplesties in Milan. In London 2013, Hadid opened her exhibition of designs and furniture at the Clerkenwell Exhibition in central London (ar). Hadid was interested in fashion and saw that it gave her an opportunity to express a set of ideas in a different size and with various tools, considering it part of the ongoing research in the world of design as a whole. Zaha Hadid applied new architectural methods to fashion, where she applied and learned from it as well, so that many common denominators appeared between architecture, fashion, and art in recent times (ar). Hadid's creations extended to the world of fashion where prestigious global names collaborated with her, leaving a distinctive legacy. In 2006, she collaborated with Louis Vuitton to produce a bag bearing the same brand, where Hadid created a bucket-shaped bag made of molded white plastic, and covered its interior with crimson leather. 2008 was considered a joyful, rich year for Hadid, where she collaborated with Lacoste and launched a shoe with a long tongue of soft leather that wraps around the leg. In the same year, she designed Neil Barrett's fashion boutique in Tokyo. Then with the Brazilian brand Melissa, she designed a plastic shoe that mimics architectural structures. Then she worked with United Nude shoes, and their first collaboration resulted in the launch of Nova shoes in 2013, a vinyl shoe plated with chrome rubber with leather on the outside, with a light platform and a fiberglass heel. The roles continued to launch with Danish jewelry John Jensen designs that focus on sculpture, and repetition of body curves, in addition to including architectural masterpieces. She collaborated with Stuart Weitzman boutiques and Hadid designed more than one store for Stuart Weitzman, the first of which was the Milan boutique that opened in September 2014 where she made the walls of fiberglass. The Fendi House brand also had a role where Hadid redefined the Peekaboo bag in 2014 for the charity project that the brand launched at the time, and the bag was sold at a Sotheby's auction, and the money went to children's charities. The architect drew inspiration for crystal bracelets in warm bright colors for Swarovski. Adidas shoes also had a role in these creations, where Hadid worked on designing Adidas Originals Superstar sports shoes with Pharrell Williams. She also collaborated with the Lebanese jewelry house Aziz and Walid Mouzannar, and the jewelry was launched in 2016 (ar). In 2015, she designed "B.zero1 Design Legend" rings in white, yellow, and rose gold for Bulgari (ru). ### Neil Barrett Aoyama Store In September 2008, she collaborated with Patrik Schumacher of Zaha Hadid Architects to design the interior of the reopened Aoyama store of Italian fashion brand Neil Barrett. This was her first foray into shop design. Neil Barrett, who commissioned the store design, said in an interview: "I loved everything about her style, including its floating presence" and "We had many discussions during this project, but she never imposed her ideas on me. I was satisfied when I saw the first sketches and thought, 'This is it!'" It was the only architectural work by Zaha Hadid that could be seen in Japan, but it closed on August 18, 2013 (ja). ### Architectural Firm Her architectural design firm, [Zaha Hadid Architects](/article/en/Zaha_Hadid_Architects), employs 400 people. Its headquarters from 1985 were in a Victorian former-school building in Clerkenwell, London. In 2021 they moved to Goswell Road, Clerkenwell. Hadid established an architectural firm named Zaha Hadid Architects in New York. One of the notable buildings designed by this agency is the boutique pavilion of Il Makiage. The firm was established in a former elementary school in London. Until ten years ago, only one classroom was her office, with the other classrooms rented out, but now the entire school is used, with a gallery-cum-office nearby. With branch offices in Hamburg and China, a total of 430 people worked there, including 250 in London (ja). Since 2011, Zaha Hadid Architects maintained an office near the Speicherstadt in Hamburg for a few years in addition to its headquarters in Clerkenwell, London. The London architectural office is located in a former Victorian school and employed about 250 people in 2012. In 2015, there were around 400 architects working on over 950 projects in 44 countries (de). ## Reputation Following her death in March 2016, Michael Kimmelman of The New York Times wrote: "her soaring structures left a mark on skylines and imaginations and in the process re-shaped architecture for the modern age...Her buildings elevated uncertainty to an art, conveyed in the odd way of one entered and moved through these buildings and in the questions that her structures raised about how they were supported ... Hadid embodied, in its profligacy and promise, the era of so-called starchitects who roamed the planet in pursuit of their own creative genius, offering miracles, occasionally delivering." She is quoted as saying "I don't make nice little buildings." Deyan Sudjic of The Guardian described Hadid as "an architect who first imagined, then proved, that space could work in radical new ways ... Throughout her career, she was a dedicated teacher, enthused by the energy of the young. She was not keen to be characterized as a woman architect, or an Arab architect. She was simply an architect." In an interview published in Icon magazine, she said: "I never use the issue about being a woman architect ... but if it helps younger people to know they can break through the glass ceiling, I don't mind that." However, she admitted that she never really felt a part of the male-dominant architecture "establishment." She once said "As a woman in architecture you're always an outsider. It's OK, I like being on the edge." Sometimes called the "Queen of the curve," Hadid was frequently described in the press as the world's top female architect, although her work also attracted criticism. The Metropolitan Museum in New York cited her "unconventional buildings that seem to defy the logic of construction." Her architectural language was described as "famously extravagant" and she was accused of building "dictator states." Architect Sean Griffiths characterized Hadid's work as "an empty vessel that sucks in whatever ideology might be in proximity to it." In 2013, Hadid founded a charitable organization, the [Zaha Hadid Foundation](/article/en/Zaha_Hadid_Foundation). It became operational in 2022 to look after Hadid's legacy and a collection of over 15,000 works by or related to Hadid, and is the only architectural foundation dedicated to a solo woman of color. The foundation operates from buildings formerly occupied by the Design Museum at Shad Thames and Zaha Hadid Architects at Bowling Green Lane, London. ## Qatar Controversy As the architect of a stadium to be used for the [2022 FIFA World Cup](/article/en/2022_FIFA_World_Cup) in Qatar, Hadid was accused in The New York Review of Books of giving an interview in which she allegedly showed no concern for the deaths of migrant workers in Qatar involved in the project. In August 2014, Hadid sued The New York Review of Books for defamation and won. Immediately thereafter, the reviewer and author of the piece in which she was accused of showing no concern issued a retraction in which he said "work did not begin on the site for the Al Wakrah stadium, until two months after Ms Hadid made those comments; and construction is not scheduled to begin until 2015 ... There have been no worker deaths on the Al Wakrah project and Ms Hadid's comments about Qatar that I quoted in the review had nothing to do with the Al Wakrah site or any of her projects. I regret the error." ## Style The architectural style of Hadid is not easily categorized, and she did not describe herself as a follower of any one style or school. Nonetheless, before she had built a single major building, she was categorized by the Metropolitan Museum of Art as a major figure in architectural [Deconstructivism](/article/en/Deconstructivism). Her work was also described as an example of [neo-futurism](/article/en/Neo-futurism) and [parametricism](/article/en/Parametricism). An article profiling Hadid in the New Yorker magazine was titled "The Abstractionist." At the time when technology was integrating into design, Zaha accepted the use of technology but still continued to hand draw her buildings and make models of the designs. This was because she did not want to limit herself and her designs to only to what the computer could do. Through her design style, she paints the conceptual designs of her many projects in fluid and geometrical forms where "Zaha Hadid's work took shape." These would be large paintings that would aspire towards her design process and "rational nature of her construction, the drawings pulled the parts and pieces apart, exploding its site and programme." When she was awarded the Pritzker Prize in 2004, the jury chairman, Lord Rothschild, commented: "At the same time as her theoretical and academic work, as a practicing architect, Zaha Hadid has been unswerving in her commitment to modernism. Always inventive, she's moved away from existing typology, from high tech, and has shifted the geometry of buildings." The Design Museum described her work in 2016 as having "the highly expressive, sweeping fluid forms of multiple perspective points and fragmented geometry that evoke the chaos and flux of modern life." Hadid herself, who often used dense architectural jargon, could also describe the essence of her style very simply: "The idea is not to have any 90-degree angles. In the beginning, there was the diagonal. The diagonal comes from the idea of the explosion which 're-forms' the space. This was an important discovery." According to Hadid herself, the surge of interest in her work began after the [Guggenheim Museum Bilbao](/article/en/Guggenheim_Museum_Bilbao) was built in 1997 based on Frank Gehry's design. After participating in the construction of the Rosenthal Center for Contemporary Art in Cincinnati, USA, which opened in 2003, her ideas became truly in demand (ru). As an architect, Hadid always tried to break conventional canons and "stretch" the framework of familiar space, giving it a powerful dynamic impulse. For the same purpose — to enhance internal movement and deformation — Zaha Hadid used distorted perspective, revealing sharp angles and curved lines. In her interviews, she repeatedly said that her creative method was formed under the influence of Russian constructivism (ru). Zaha Hadid was committed to the deconstructivist school, which focuses on modern style and design, and implemented 950 projects in 44 countries. Her work was characterized by imagination, as she created designs with free-flowing lines unrestrained by horizontal or vertical boundaries. Her work was also characterized by durability, as she used steel in her designs. The Vitra Fire Station in Germany (1993), the MAXXI Museum of Italian Art in Rome (2009), the American Museum in Cincinnati, the Sheikh Zayed Bridge in Abu Dhabi, the London Aquatics Centre for the 2012 Olympic Games, the Strasbourg Metro Station, the Cultural Center in Azerbaijan, the Science Center in Wolfsburg, the Maritime Terminal in Salerno, the Ski Jump in Innsbruck, and the Heydar Aliyev Cultural Center in Baku (2013) are among the most prominent projects that deservedly brought Hadid to the global stage (ar). According to Hadid herself, the surge of interest in her work began after the Guggenheim Museum in Bilbao was built in 1997 based on Frank Gehry's design. After participating in the construction of the Rosenthal Center for Contemporary Art in Cincinnati, USA, which opened in 2003, her ideas became truly in demand (ru). Strongly influenced by Russian Constructivist architecture and art, she creates conceptual and imaginative works in real space, surprising visitors and users. Previously, like fellow deconstructivist Daniel Libeskind, she was mainly known as an advocate of architectural thought and a creator of drawings showing radical concepts rather than actual architectural works (ja). Her work is characterized by drawings of countless road-like or pipe-like lines that gently bend, intersect, and overlap while flowing at high speed, and futuristic, massive organic structures (ja). According to Mitsuhiro Kaneda (a structural engineer at Arup Tokyo office in 2012), "In addition to her commitment to form, the fusion of architecture and facade is very important" (ja). Hadid's interest in architecture began when she went with her family on a trip to visit the ruins of the Sumerian civilization in southern Iraq, which is considered the oldest civilization known to mankind. Zaha says in an interview with The Guardian: "My father took us to visit the Sumerian cities, and we went by boat and then continued in a smaller boat made of reed bundles. The beauty of the landscapes there, with sand, water, birds, buildings, and people, has remained in my memory since that moment. I am trying to discover, or invent, an architectural style and forms of urban planning that have the same effect, but in a more modern way" (ar). Zaha was greatly influenced by the work of Brazilian architect [Oscar Niemeyer](/article/en/Oscar_Niemeyer), especially his sense of space, as well as his exceptional talent. His works had inspired and encouraged her to create her own style, emulating his search for fluidity in all forms. Zaha Hadid's works were characterized by a clear architectural direction in all her works, known as deconstructivism or destructionism, an approach that involves high complexity and irregular geometry. She also used steel in her designs to withstand high degrees of tension and pressure loads, which enabled her to execute free and bold formations. She was also distinguished by her architectural works with potential energy, in addition to the authenticity and originality of her works, with high dynamism. Zaha Hadid played an active role in changing the concept of architecture in the world. Hadid contributed to creating a better world through her elegant designs for buildings, and her designs were considered unique, as if they belonged to the world of imagination on another planet (ar). This trend appeared in 1971 and is considered one of the most important architectural movements that emerged in the twentieth century. This trend generally calls for the demolition of all the foundations of Euclidean geometry, attributed to the Greek mathematician Euclid, by deconstructing structures into parts. Despite the differences and contradictions between the pioneers of this trend, they agree on one fundamental thing: differing from everything that is familiar and traditional (ar). Zaha believed that her designs interact with the city and give people a place to communicate, saying that followers of her work know that creating public spaces that people can use freely allows the city to flow in a smooth and easy way. What distinguished these designs is that they took a clear architectural direction based on an artistic and philosophical background, so they tended toward the imaginative and abstract. According to Jencks' classification of deconstructive architecture, Zaha Hadid's works fall within the modern constructivist trend, which was also associated with the works of Rem Koolhaas. Their vision is summarized in that it is based on strange and inclined supports, enjoys fluidity and deconstruction in defying gravity through insistence on flying ceilings and beams, with an emphasis on the dynamics of formation, to the extent that Zaha Hadid's works were called dynamic abstraction (ar). ## Imagination and Controversy Imagination and idealism characterize Zaha Hadid's designs, which some claim are impossible to implement, as her buildings are based on strange and inclined supports, and some critics assert that these designs are overwhelmed by a state of strictness (ar). Meanwhile, the Iraqi architect practically refuted accusations by some critics that she was a "paper engineer," meaning that her designs were difficult to implement, after the completion of the Science Museum in Wolfsburg, northern Germany, which opened in November 2005, confirming that the claim of "paper engineer" was nothing but a false allegation from architects living with the past; because everything she put on her computer screen, others were able to implement, as reported by Al-Sharqiya website (ar). One critic said about her: "All her designs are in fluid motion, not defined by vertical or horizontal lines; it is not the architecture of women; she is a sensitive artist, presenting what she feels from the impact of technical and artistic development in all its directions in a world that has become a small village" (ar). Architectural critic Andreas Ruby said about her creations and designs: "Zaha Hadid's projects resemble spaceships, floating without the influence of gravity in a vast space, with no high or low part, no face or back, they are buildings that appear as if in fluid motion in the surrounding space, and from the initial idea stage of Zaha's projects to the implementation stage; the spacecraft approaches the Earth's surface, and in its stability is considered the largest maneuvering operation in the field of architecture." Her partner Patrick Schumacher described her as: "A scream in what she presented, for two decades, in both drawing and architecture" (ar). With Hadid's growing success, the number of her critics and the sharpness of the attacks on her also increased, increasingly organized in campaigns after construction awards or inaugurations. Finally, some critics attempted to associate her work with totalitarianism. For example, architect Michael Murphy described her work in an ambiguous way as "famously extravagant," as she created some of her projects for clients from "dictator states" such as China and Azerbaijan. Architect Sean Griffiths, one of her most determined opponents ("more outspoken than most"), attacked Hadid's work as an empty vessel and thus ideal for ideologies of any color (de). Wolf D. Prix of [Coop Himmelb(l)au](/article/en/Coop_Himmelblau), who like many other architects builds in China and Azerbaijan, defended Hadid in 2014: "The discussions about Zaha Hadid's architectures are becoming increasingly ridiculous. She is famous, has many commissions, and this arouses envy. I don't know any architect who, faced with the question of building a cultural center according to his ideas in Baku or not, would have determinedly rejected this commission for moral reasons. But I know many architects who were never asked and are therefore all the more indignant in condemning those who accept commissions from so-called dictatorships. But the question is not whether one can build in authoritarian societies, but how one builds." On the one hand, architects today are burdened with ever greater, even "seemingly moral" obligations, while at the same time their influence on the building process is becoming increasingly smaller (de). A second level of criticism focuses on the aesthetics of Zaha Hadid's work. For example, art historian Maike Aden interprets the MAXXI Museum in Rome as a "seclusion" from the public and urban life, which she illustrates with several fence photos. The MAXXI thus carries "the unmistakable message of a de-democratization of art." This "seclusion" she perceives is so great that the museum can no longer be compensated for with "low-threshold" or "more diversified" museum education and "more public relations work." In fact, the outer fence only serves to protect art objects that are exhibited around the museum and are located away from the large piazza in front of the entrance. In her thesis on the MAXXI, art historian Herta Gurtner comes to the opposite conclusion, namely that it "succeeded [...] in designing the area open and inviting for everyone, not just for museum visitors" (de). In a general way, art historian Laura Weißmüller judged in the Süddeutsche Zeitung that Zaha Hadid did not want to be restricted and developed an aesthetic form language that was so clear "that it eventually covered the function - and the place where the building stood." This blanket judgment also contradicts Hadid's understanding of her buildings, which she primarily saw as "bridges" intended to connect people (de). ## Awards and Honours Hadid was appointed Commander of the Order of the British Empire (CBE) in the 2002 Birthday Honours and Dame Commander of the Order of the British Empire (DBE) in the 2012 Birthday Honours for services to architecture. Hadid was named an honorary member of the American Academy of Arts and Letters and an honorary fellow of the American Institute of Architects. She was on the board of trustees of The Architecture Foundation. In 2002, Hadid won the international design competition to design Singapore's one-north master plan. In 2004, Hadid became the first female recipient of the Pritzker Architecture Prize. In 2005, her design won the competition for the new city casino of Basel, Switzerland and she was elected as a Royal Academician. In 2006, she was honored with a retrospective spanning her entire work at the Guggenheim Museum in New York; that year she also received an Honorary Degree from the American University of Beirut. In 2008, she was ranked 69th on the Forbes list of "The World's 100 Most Powerful Women." In 2010, she was named by Time as an influential thinker in the 2010 TIME 100 issue. In September 2010 the New Statesman listed Zaha Hadid at number 42 in its annual survey of "The World's 50 Most Influential Figures of 2010." In 2013, she was assessed as one of the 100 most powerful women in the UK by Woman's Hour on BBC Radio 4. In 2014, 2015 and 2016, Hadid appeared on Debrett's list of the most influential people in the UK. In January 2015, she was nominated for the Services to Science and Engineering award at the British Muslim Awards. She won the Stirling Prize, the UK's most prestigious award for architecture, two years running: in 2010, for one of her most celebrated works, the MAXXI in Rome, and in 2011 for the Evelyn Grace Academy, a Z‑shaped school in Brixton, London. She also designed the Dongdaemun Design Plaza & Park in Seoul, South Korea, which was the centerpiece of the festivities for the city's designation as World Design Capital 2010. In 2014, the Heydar Aliyev Cultural Centre, designed by her, won the Design Museum Design of the Year Award, making her the first woman to win the top prize in that competition. In 2015, she became the first woman to receive the Royal Gold Medal awarded by the Royal Institute of British Architects. In 2016 in Antwerp, Belgium a square was named after her, Zaha Hadidplein, in front of the extension of the Antwerp Harbour House designed by Zaha Hadid. Google celebrated her achievements with a Doodle on 31 May 2017, to commemorate the date (in 2004) on which Hadid became the first woman to win the prestigious Pritzker Architecture Prize. Zaha Hadid received numerous prestigious awards, medals, and honorary titles in the field of architecture. She was one of the first women to receive the Pritzker Prize in Architecture in 2004, which is equivalent in value to the Nobel Prize in Engineering. She won the Stirling Prize on two occasions and was awarded the Order of the British Empire and the Japanese Imperial Order in 2012. She also received the Royal Gold Medal from the Royal Institute of British Architects (RIBA) in 2016, becoming the first woman to receive this honor. She was described as the most powerful engineer in the world and believed that the field of architectural engineering was not exclusive to men. She achieved Arab and global accomplishments and did not limit herself to architectural designs but also designed furniture and even shoes. Prestigious global names were eager to collaborate with Hadid, which led her critics to call her the Lady Gaga of the engineering world. She was ranked as the fourth most powerful woman in the world in 2010 (ar). Zaha Hadid represented a success story starring a well-known architectural woman, who traveled the world achieving numerous accomplishments, starting from Baghdad. Hadid harvested many awards, medals, honorary titles, and certificates of appreciation from architecture legends such as Japanese Kenzo Tange, and her name jumped to the ranks of the world's architectural giants. The Iraqi engineer won the highest Austrian award in 2002; she received the Austrian State Tourism Award. She was chosen as the fourth most powerful woman in the world in 2010 according to Time magazine's classification. UNESCO had included Hadid in the list of Artists for Peace who use their influence and global reputation to promote the organization's ideals, where it praised in a statement her efforts in the field of architectural art and her role in raising public awareness of intellectual dialogue and excellence in the field of design and creativity and her dedication to serving the ideals and goals of the organization. The selection process came after she topped the thinkers category in Time magazine's list of the hundred most influential personalities in the world. Hadid ranked sixty-eighth among the world's most powerful women according to the annual ranking announced by Forbes business magazine, where German Chancellor Angela Merkel occupied the first place for the second year in a row on the list of the hundred most powerful women in the world (ar). In 2004, Zaha Hadid won the Pritzker Prize awarded by the Hyatt Foundation, owner of the Regency hotels chain, to a living architect, which is equivalent in value to the Nobel Prize, with a material value of $100,000 accompanied by a bronze medal. She was the youngest person to win it at the time, where the jury praised the urban achievements Hadid had accomplished and described them as "important and lasting contributions to humanity." The prize was awarded to her after she won the competition to build the Rosenthal Center for Modern Art in Cincinnati, Ohio, in 2004. In 2006, the American University in Beirut awarded her an honorary doctorate in recognition of her efforts, in addition to receiving the Order of the Empire with the rank of Commander from France (ar). In 2007, she was awarded the Thomas Jefferson Award for Architecture, in recognition of her serious and unique contribution to architecture. It is an award given to architects since 1966 on an annual basis. In 2012, she received the Japanese Imperial Order and the Order of Merit from Queen Elizabeth, and was chosen as the best personality in Britain. Zaha Hadid became an honorary member of the American Academy of Arts and Letters and the American Institute of Architects (ar). In 2014, she won the London Design Museum Award for her design of the Heydar Aliyev Center in Azerbaijan. In 2016, she won the RIBA Royal Gold Medal for Architecture. The Iraqi architect Zaha became the first woman to receive this award, which is the highest honor presented by the Royal British Institute in recognition of historical achievement in the field of architecture. Zaha Hadid has a fortune estimated at $215 million (ar). ### Selected Awards 1982: Gold Medal Architectural Design, British Architecture for 59 Eaton Place, London 1994: Erich Schelling Architecture Award 2001: Équerre d'argent Prize, special mention 2002: Austrian State Prize for Architecture for Bergiselschanze 2003: European Union Prize for Contemporary Architecture for the Strasbourg tramway terminus and car park in Hoenheim, France 2003: Commander of the Civil Division of the Order of the British Empire (CBE) for services to architecture 2004: Pritzker Prize 2005: Austrian Decoration for Science and Art 2005: German Architecture Prize for the central building of the BMW plant in Leipzig 2005: Designer of the Year Award for Design Miami 2005: RIBA European Award for BMW Central Building 2006: RIBA European Award for Phaeno Science Centre 2007: Thomas Jefferson Medal in Architecture 2008: RIBA European Award for Nordpark Cable Railway 2009: Praemium Imperiale 2010: RIBA European Award for MAXXI 2012: Jane Drew Prize for her "outstanding contribution to the status of women in architecture" 2012: Jury member for the awarding of the Pritzker Prize to Wang Shu in Los Angeles. 2013: 41st Winner of the Veuve Clicquot UK Business Woman Award 2013: Elected international member, American Philosophical Society Medal of Academician Mikail Useynov (2013). Honorary member of the Union of Architects of Azerbaijan (2013). She was also on the editorial board of the Encyclopædia Britannica. ## Honors and Memorials ### Honor from the American University of Beirut The American University of Beirut honored the famous architect after her death, where it held an exhibition of her most important works from May 9 to May 13, 2016, at the Issam Fares Institute for Public Policy and International Affairs, which Hadid designed and which opened in 2014. Pictures from her life, family, and the jewelry she designed were displayed (ar). ### The Central Bank of Iraq's Obituary The President of the Bank said in a statement: "He received with great sorrow the news of the death of the great Iraqi architect Zaha Hadid, who excelled in many of her architectural designs, including the new building of the Central Bank of Iraq, which is hoped to begin construction work in early 2017." The Central Bank of Iraq added that in honor of this Iraqi creator, it was decided to establish a memorial for her at the new site in Al-Jadriya, central Baghdad (ar). ### The American University of Beirut's Obituary The American University of Beirut mourned Mrs. Zaha Hadid, one of the most prominent creative architectural engineers of the current era, who was a former student at the university, and the designer of one of its most distinctive buildings (ar). ## Writings and Publications ### Translations into Persian "Eighty-nine degrees" in the book Theories and Manifestos of Contemporary Architecture; Compiled and edited by Charles Jencks, translated by Ehsan Hanif, Fekr-e-No Publications, 2018.
